thread.section_title: Financial Review - Business, Finance and Investment News | afr.com
thread.title: Investor demand cools in Sydney's housing market
thread.title_full: Investor demand cools in Sydney's housing market | afr.com

author: Matthew Cranston
title: Investor demand cools in Sydney's housing market
text:
Investors are making up a smaller pool of those borrowing for houses Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Matthew Cranston Australia's biggest wholesale mortgage broker AFG reports large decline in investor property loans over the month of May giving the clearest signal yet that Sydney's housing market is starting to cool.
While the mortgage broker announced a record-breaking volume of $5.1 billion in mortgages processed for the month of June – up 34.5 per cent on June last year - it also reported a "significant cooling" in investment loans.
Investment loans were accounted for 36.9 per cent of the national pool of mortgages down from a peak of 43.1 per cent in April.
The figures follow reports from Mortgage Choice that a clampdown on lending to landlords has dragged property investors' share of its loan approvals to a 20-month low .
New South Wales, the home of Sydney's booming market, made up 41.6 per cent of investment loans in June down from 49.8 per cent in May. Investment loans had been running at an average of 49.5 per cent of all loans in NSW for the previous 12 months. The decline also comes as auction clearance rates trend down in Sydney .
"These figures suggest that APRA controls are starting to take effect, but not at the expense of the overall mortgage market," AFG managing director Brett McKeon said, "If this trend continues, it should help allay concerns about overheating in Sydney, in particular, as investment levels there come back into line with the sustainable, long term, national average."
The listed AFG has a loan book of more than $100 billion and its figures give an accurate picture of the type of home buyers borrowing.
Throughout Australia, the same moderating trend was repeated, with investment loans declining in South Australia from 41.8 per cent to 36.8 per cent, in Queensland from 36.1 per cent to 34.1 per cent and in Victoria from 36.5 per cent to 35.7 per cent. Western Australia saw a drop to 31.2 per cent from from 31.8 per cent.
 There has also been a significant change in who is lending to home buyers. Last month saw 30.9 per cent of all mortgages processed for non-major lenders – the highest such figure since 32.5 per cent recorded in December last year.
More to come.
